I think it'd be good to include a new method type on tests: Does any 
of the tests within the class require an enviornment to run in.  

An excellent example of this is the case where a test reads from a 
database.  Unless the DB is set up, the test will fail. 

Differentiating between completely standalone tests (eg StingUtility 
classes) or requires a test environment (eg database, file structure) 
would be terrific, especially with the Ant junit batchtest structure, 
where Ant works its way through the code and finds Tester classes to 
run.  It doesn't have any way of knowing the environment that it's 
running in, or the environment that the test needs.

For example:

a new method

String getProject() - Returns the name of the project.  Allows for 
simple "namespaces" for test environments.

String[] getTestEnvironments() - that returns a list of required test 
environments (by name).  

Updated JUnit testrunners that will by default run all tests 
regardless of environment.  New JUnit testrunners that take a list of 
available projects/test environmnets as parameters, and only run 
those tests that run in available environments.

All of which would be upwardly compatible.

Any thoughts?

David Ford
